Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 54148-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (TA) 
June 2020 
 
 
 
 
Scaling Up Private Sector Participation in the 
Infrastructure Sector in the Central and West Asia 
Region 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 
CST  –  Client Solutions Team 
CWA  –  Central and West Asia  
CWRD  –  Central and West Asia Department 
DMC  –  developing member country  
GIF  –  Global Infrastructure Facility 
MDB  –  multilateral development bank 
OPPP  –  Office of Public–Private Partnership 
PIM  –  project identification memo 
PPP  –  public–private partnership 
PSA  –  public sector agency 
PSOD  –  Private Sector Operations Department 
PSP  –  private sector participation 
PSR  –  project screening report 
TA  –  technical assistance 
TORs  –  terms of reference 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
 
Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Werner E. Liepach, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  Peter Marro, Advisor and Head, Client Solutions Team (CST), Office of 
the Director General, CWRD 
   
Team leaders  Almazbek Galiev, Principal Public–Private Partnership Specialist, CST, 
CWRD 
Dmitry Kabrelyan, Senior Public–Private Partnership Specialist, CST, 
CWRD 
Team members  Marian Therese Bartolome, Senior Operations Assistant, CST, CWRD 
  Ting-Ying Lin, Young Professional, CST, CWRD 
  Arleen Mabale, Project Officer (Public–Private Partnership), CST, CWRD 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the development of a 
scalable pipeline of infrastructure projects that  can  attract  private  sector  investments  and 
generate efficiency gains through (i) the screening of new and existing projects in the deal 
pipelines developed by the developing member country (DMC)  governments and their  public 
sector agencies (PSAs);1 and (ii) the provision of capacity building-related  assistance,  including 
knowledge sharing and training events in the Central and West Asia (CWA) region.2 The TA will 
also help develop credible concepts for the (i) introduction and/or strengthening of sustainable 
and  integrated  financing  solutions,  and  (ii)  deployment  of  efficient  and  responsive  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) transaction support to augment public–private partnerships (PPPs) and 
private sector participation (PSP)3 for the delivery of infrastructure projects in the CWA region.4  
 
2.  The  TA  responds  directly  to  ADB’s  Strategy  2030,5 which  identifies  private  sector 
operations, including PPPs, and strengthening of ADB’s knowledge services as key operational 
priorities. The TA is also consistent with ADB’s Public–Private Partnership Operational Plan 
2012–2020,6 which  requires  ADB’s  regional  departments  to  assume  a  leadership  role  in 
advocating PPPs within DMCs. 7 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Rising financing needs and gaps. Central Asia needs to invest an average of $33 billion 
annually in infrastructure until 2030 to maintain its growth momentum and tackle poverty,8 
excluding the cost of responding to climate change. PSP, including PPPs, are considered to be 
an important modality for attracting private investment in infrastructure and enhancing efficiency 
of infrastructure services. 
 
4.  Despite the importance of PSP projects and PPPs, PSAs lack the necessary capacity and 
experience to identify, structure and procure credible and bankable PSP projects and PPPs and 
scale up PSP for the provision of infrastructure services. Most PSP and PPP pipelines are 
developed solely with reference to the DMC priority infrastructure needs and do not assess the 
value added by the PSP and PPP modalities, the potential market risk appetite, and the projects’ 
ultimate bankability and scalability. 
 
 
1  These include central and local governments, government agencies (including subsovereign and government-owned 
entities), and other entities eligible to receive assistance from the Asian Development Bank. 
2  The CWA region includes Afghanistan, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyz Republic, Pakistan, 
Tajikistan, Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan.  
3  Examples include PPPs (including partnerships involving management and operating contracts, concessional 
design–build–finance–operate–maintain  contracts,  and  partial  divestitures)  or  privatizations  (full  or  partial 
divestitures). Projects and developments that do not involve a key public sector counterparty will not be supported 
by the TA. 
4  Projects include energy infrastructure (such as power stations, transmission and distribution lines, and substations); 
transport infrastructure (such as ports, airports, railways, roads, and bridges); urban development infrastructure (such 
as water and waste management projects); agricultural infrastructure; and social infrastructure (such as healthcare 
or education projects). 
5  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
6  ADB. 2012. Public–Private Partnership Operational Plan 2012–2020. Manila. 
7  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 18 May 2020. 
8  ADB. 2017. Meeting Asia's Infrastructure Needs. Manila. Data on Afghanistan and Pakistan are excluded from the 
cost estimate (they are included in the infrastructure needs estimates for South Asia).

2 
5.  Insufficient access to private sector resources. Historically, sovereign borrowing has 
been the major source of financing for infrastructure in the CWA region. Given the constrained 
fiscal budgets, which will be further impacted by the ongoing coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
pandemic,9 there is a need to significantly increase the access by potential projects to a full range 
of private sector funding sources, including long-term institutional investors (e.g., pension funds 
and  insurance  companies)  and  commercial  banks.  The  circumstances  necessitate  the 
development and implementation of integrated financing solutions to augment PSP and PPP 
projects for sustainable infrastructure delivery. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impacts and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impacts: (i) sustainability of private sector investments 
in infrastructure projects in ADB’s Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) DMCs improved; 
(ii) DMCs’ capacity to plan, develop, and sustainably finance infrastructure using PSP and PPP 
modalities increased; and (iii) ADB’s knowledge services strengthened (footnote 5). The TA will 
have the following outcome: CWRD DMCs’ capacity in identification, preparation and financial 
support of sustainable and gender sensitive infrastructure PSP projects and PPPs improved. 10  
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  The TA will have three key outputs. While the largest output and fund allocation will be for 
output 2, outputs 1 and 3 are designed to feed into output 2 and ensure sustainability and 
continuity when the TA is completed. 
 
8.  Output  1:  Private  sector  participation  projects  and  public-private  partnerships 
identified and initially screened. The TA will help identify and develop project screening reports 
(PSRs) for at least 6 scalable pilot infrastructure projects, in various sectors and DMCs in CWA. 
The project screening process will involve the relevant resident missions and sector divisions of 
ADB’s  CWRD,  Office  of  Public–Private  Partnership  (OPPP),  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department (PSOD), sector and thematic groups, and other ADB departments, thereby bringing 
together the knowledge and expertise across ADB and accelerating the One ADB approach in 
the CWA region. 
 
9.  The project screening process will comprise a high-level assessment with the objective of 
determining if the project can be appropriately structured with PSP; is potentially economically 
and financially viable and fiscally responsible (i.e., commercial revenues and other operational 
cash flows to the project are likely to cover costs, including debt service obligations). The project 
screening  process  will  also  assess  the  adequacy  of  the  government’s  fiscal  capacity  and 
resources and its willingness to pay for or subsidize the services, if necessary. The project 
screening process will examine relevant gender and social inclusion issues and identify potential 
gender-responsive, socially inclusive design features. 
 
10.  Output  2:  Private  sector  participation  projects  and  public-private  partnerships 
financing solutions and transaction support developed. The PSRs resulting from this process 
 
9  The TA is not designed solely for projects that address the COVID-19 pandemic, but it is anticipated that some 
transactions under the TA will be in the health sector or related to other sectors affected by the COVID-19 crisis. 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
will clarify the basis for advocating the most appropriate (i) gender-responsive, socially inclusive, 
sustainable, and innovative private sector financing solutions; and (ii) responses that can be 
deployed by ADB through its transaction support products.11 The TA will assist in the development 
of at least 2 credible and efficient concepts for potential ADB PSP and PPP transaction support 
for the introduction of sustainable, innovative, and fiscally responsible private sector financing 
solutions and promotion of gender equality in all PSP and PPP projects developed with the 
support of the TA. 
 
11.  Output 3: Transaction-focused private sector participation projects and public-
private partnerships knowledge sharing, training and capacity building activities carried 
out. The TA will support at least two regional consultation events with PPP authorities, relevant 
PSAs involved in PSP and PPP work in the CWA region, and ADB project teams; the objective 
will be to maximize responsiveness of the TA project to the needs and priorities of CWRD DMCs. 
Consultation  meetings  will  help  identify  credible  and  scalable  PSP  and  PPP  projects  and 
development opportunities in the CWA region, and help market ADB’s transaction support 
products. The consultations will also help in identifying gender-responsive and socially inclusive 
design features to be integrated in the identified projects. The consultation meetings will allow 
relevant  PSP  and  PPP  stakeholders  to  showcase  successful  gender-responsive,  socially 
inclusive PSP projects and PPPs in the CWA region to stimulate knowledge sharing and learning 
across  DMCs,  and  thereby  enable  ADB  to  advocate  credible  PSP  and  PPP  modalities, 
sustainable and fiscally responsible revenue streams, and management models and mechanisms. 
The TA will also support priority knowledge events and workshops that may emerge from the 
consultation meetings. 
 
12.  All regional consultation events will be arranged following the One ADB approach in close 
consultation with CWRD resident missions and sector divisions, OPPP, PSOD, and other ADB 
departments as appropriate. In addition to marketing the ADB transaction support products, the 
TA will disseminate knowledge and support existing PSP and PPP knowledge products supported 
by ADB and other multilateral development banks (MDBs), including the Association of Project 
Managers Group PPP Certification Program training and certification,12 Sustainable Infrastructure 
Foundation–SOURCE,13 and the ADB PPP monitor report.14  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund ($400,000 TASF-6 and $100,000 TASF-other sources). The 
key expenditures are listed in Appendix 2.  
 
14.  To leverage the TA resources, additional cofinancing of the eligible development efforts 
will be sought from existing facilities that provide financial resources and technical support for 
PSP and PPP capacity-building activities and preparation of infrastructure projects, such as 
 
11 This may include transaction advice, financing through sovereign and nonsovereign windows, credit enhancement, 
project loans, policy and results-based loans, project development funds, and other financing modalities. 
12 This is a joint initiative by several MDBs, including ADB, and partly funded by the Public–Private Infrastructure 
Advisory Facility, with a shared vision of enhancing PPP performance globally. 
13 The Sustainable Infrastructure Foundation, a nonprofit Swiss foundation headquartered in Geneva, coordinates the 
operational provision of SOURCE. SOURCE is the multilateral platform for quality infrastructure, led and funded by 
MDBs. It brings a systemic change in the way governments define, develop, and manage their infrastructure projects 
for both traditional procurement and PPPs. 
14 ADB. 2019. Public–Private Partnership Monitor: Second Edition. Manila. The PPP monitor aims to serve as a policy 
tool to create a dialogue between public and private sectors and provide an enabling environment for PPPs.

4 
the Global Infrastructure Facility (GIF),15 ADB’s Asia Pacific Project Preparation Facility, and other 
external and internal facilities established by ADB and other development partners. Provision is 
made for two regional consultation events over the TA implementation period. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will act as executing agency and will administer the TA through the newly established 
Client Solutions Team (CST) team in CWRD. The CST will select, supervise, and evaluate 
consultants. To accelerate the One ADB approach, close coordination and collaboration will be 
undertaken with CWRD’s sector divisions and resident missions, OPPP, PSOD, and other ADB 
departments and sector and thematic groups, where relevant, to promote synergies with ongoing 
development efforts. 
 
16.  Because of the diverse requirements and activities expected to be carried out under the 
TA, both individual consultants and firms will be recruited. Specific terms of reference (TORs) will 
be developed as part of the project screening process. Wherever possible, the OPPP’s framework 
agreements for individual consultants16 and firms17 will be used to ensure fast mobilization of 
consultancy services. If necessary, further framework agreements will be set up in advance to 
cover services that may be supported by the TA on a recurrent basis. The TA will maximize the 
use of available ADB expertise and will allow the participation of relevant ADB staff as resource 
persons. The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table below. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements

Implementing agencies  TBD

determined. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
 
15 GIF is a global, open collaborative platform that facilitates the preparation and structuring of complex infrastructure 
PPPs. GIF supports project screening assessments as well as project definition assistance on a purely grant basis. 
16 Each framework agreement empanels several individual consultants that can be hired directly under call-off 
assignments without competition. Currently, several framework agreements have been set up by the OPPP covering 
PPP-related services in various sectors. 
17 Up to six firms are empaneled under various sector framework agreements by the OPPP. These firms can be 
engaged under call-off contracts without the need for prior short-listing.

5 
and/or staff instructions.18 Consulting services and training programs will be on an as-needed 
basis that will respond quickly and flexibly to circumstances and demands as may be requested 
by the governments and/or identified by ADB. The TA is categorized as complex given that its 
scope involves the assessment of multiple pilot project delivery approaches, collaborative internal 
and external review procedures and processes, and the possibility of cofinancing by other 
development partners and/or facilities. 
 
18.  CST, CWRD resident missions and sector divisions, OPPP, and/or PSOD will identify 
candidate PSP projects and PPPs and prepare an initial project identification memo (PIM)19 
and/or a PSR.20 The initial PIM and PSR will highlight the critical information gaps, which shall be 
filled out and/or validated using the TA resources, and incorporate TORs for the consultancy 
services to be supported by the TA. It is expected that the estimated value of each project 
screening consultancy assignment will not exceed $50,000. CST will prioritize PIMs and PSRs 
for projects promoting cooperation and integration initiatives in the CWA region, including ADB’s 
Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program. 
 
19.  CST will discuss all initial PIMs and PSRs, including draft TORs, with the relevant CWRD 
resident mission and sector division and OPPP with the objective of finalizing the TORs and 
identifying possible cofinancing opportunities. Where determined necessary or appropriate, CST 
will involve other ADB departments and field fact-finding and consultation missions to DMCs. CST 
will finalize each PSR on the basis of the feedback received from the TA consultants and submit 
the PSR to the relevant CWRD resident mission and sector division, OPPP, and/or PSOD with 
the objective of determining if the proposed project merits further ADB transaction support. 
 
E.  Governance 
 
20.  The project screening activities under the TA will include a review of the governance 
framework in place at the level of the prospective project. Any deficiencies and the related action 
plan to address these will be shared with the relevant stakeholders as part of the PSRs. CST will 
coordinate the feedback provided to the CWRD resident missions and sector divisions, OPPP, 
PSOD, and other ADB departments, and follow up on the potential ADB transaction support that 
may originate from the project screening activities supported by the TA with the relevant ADB 
departments. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis for 
Scaling Up Private Sector Participation in the Infrastructure Sector in the Central and West Asia 
Region, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
 
18 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
19 Sample Project Identification Memo (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
20 Project Screening Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

6  Appendix 1

Key Activities with Milestonesb 
1. PSP projects and/or PPPs identified and initially screened 
1.1 Identify new and existing PSP projects and/or PPPs in the PSP/PPP pipelines of DMCs in the CWA 
region, in consultation with sector divisions and resident missions of CWRD, OPPP, PSOD, and DMCs’ 
PPP authorities (Q2 2020–Q4 2021). 
1.2 Prepare initial PSRs and identify the scope of consultancy services to be supported by the TA project 
(Q2 2020–Q4 2021). 
1.3 Recruit consultants to be funded by the TA project and review their inputs and recommendations (Q2 
2020–Q4 2021). 
1.4 Confirm preliminary feasibility of the project and identify and/or conceptualize potential further ADB 
transaction support and potential PSP and/or PPP financing support solutions (Q3 2020–Q2 2022). 
1.5 Finalize the PSP and present to relevant CWRD resident missions, sector divisions, and other ADB 
departments for decision on further actions (Q3 2020–Q2 2022). 
2. PSP and PPP financing solutions and transaction support developed 
2.1 Assess the viability of potential PSP and/or PPP financing support solutions for all screened projects 
and present the resulting concepts to the relevant CWRD resident missions, sector divisions, and other 
ADB departments (Q3 2020–Q2 2022). 
3. Transaction-focused PSP and/or PPP knowledge sharing, training and capacity building activities 
carried out 
3.1 Identify the PPP authorities and key stakeholders in the CWA region DMCs through the CWRD 
resident missions and sector divisions (Q2 2020–Q2 2022). 
3.2 Identify CWRD resident missions and/or PPP agencies that agree to host initial and subsequent 
consultation meetings (Q2 2020–Q2 2022). 
3.3 Reach agreement with the relevant CWRD resident missions and sector divisions, OPPP, PSOD, and 
other departments on the agenda for the first and subsequent consultation meetings (Q2 2020–Q3 
2022). 
3.4 Hold regional consultation meetings in collaboration with relevant CWRD resident missions and sector 
divisions, OPPP, PSOD, and other departments (Q3 2020–Q3 2022). 
3.5 Hold specific knowledge-sharing and training events as may be identified and agreed during the 
consultation meetings (Q3 2020–Q3 2022). 
TA Management Activities 
Hire consultants

ADB:  $500,000 Technical Assistance Special Fund ($400,000 TASF-6 and $100,000 TASF-other sources)

8  Appendix 1 
Assumptions for Partner Financing

Facility, and other sources

CWRD = Central and West Asia Department, DMC = developing member countries, OPPP = Office of Public–Private 
Partnership, PPP = public–private partnership, PSOD = Private Sector Operations Department, PSP = private sector 
participation, PSR = project screening report, Q = quarter, TA = technical assistance.

Source: Asian Development Bank.
